20110127012301.000|20110127012303.000|TR0|SPITZER:  Violence and revolt in Egypt 
20110127012303.000|20110127012305.000|TR0|tonight, a country that was until now 
20110127012305.000|20110127012308.000|TR0|America's most stable ally in the Middle 
20110127012308.000|20110127012310.000|TR0|East.  Thousands of protesters took to the 
20110127012310.000|20110127012312.000|TR0|streets for a second day calling for the 
20110127012312.000|20110127012315.000|TR0|resignation of President Hosni Mubarak.
20110127012315.000|20110127012317.000|TR0|

20110127012319.000|20110127012322.000|TR0|teargas, batons and water canons.  Four 
20110127012322.000|20110127012324.000|TR0|people have died.  More than 100 are

20110127012326.000|20110127012328.000|TR0|worse.

20110127012928.000|20110127012930.000|TR0|point out is that Egypt has never put any

20110127012932.000|20110127012934.000|TR0|to any site they want.  However, yesterday 
20110127012934.000|20110127012937.000|TR0|during the protests, Twitter suddenly was 
20110127012937.000|20110127012939.000|TR0|blocked and that was one of the main forms 
20110127012939.000|20110127012941.000|TR0|of spreading information and spreading 
20110127012941.000|20110127012944.000|TR0|news about Egypt.
20110127012944.000|20110127012946.000|TR0|

20110127012948.000|20110127012951.000|TR0|nothing.  They say that the system was 
20110127012951.000|20110127012953.000|TR0|overwhelmed and it simply didn't function 
20110127012953.000|20110127012955.000|TR0|in Egypt.  And what's interesting is that 
20110127012955.000|20110127012957.000|TR0|it took about an hour and a half ago, 
20110127012957.000|20110127013000.000|TR0|mid-evening in Cairo, the Twitter page was 
20110127013000.000|20110127013002.000|TR0|working again, but Twitter and Facebook, 
20110127013002.000|20110127013004.000|TR0|things like text messages have been key to 
20110127013004.000|20110127013007.000|TR0|spread the word to organize these 
20110127013007.000|20110127013009.000|TR0|demonstrations and to keep them going and 
20110127013009.000|20110127013011.000|TR0|to spread information so Egyptians even at 
20110127013011.000|20110127013014.000|TR0|these demonstrations, they're half the 
20110127013014.000|20110127013016.000|TR0|time chanting, the other time they're 
20110127013016.000|20110127013018.000|TR0|looking down at their mobile phones to 
20110127013018.000|20110127013021.000|TR0|read text messages to check Facebook, to 
20110127013021.000|20110127013023.000|TR0|check Twitter.  So it's a very techie 
20110127013023.000|20110127013025.000|TR0|revolution if we can call it that.
20110127013025.000|20110127013027.000|TR0|
20110127013027.000|20110127013030.000|TR0|SPITZER:  Who are the protesters?

20110127013041.000|20110127013044.000|TR0|There are Islamists.  There are sort of 
20110127013044.000|20110127013046.000|TR0|every sector of Egyptians deciding.
20110127013046.000|20110127013048.000|TR0|
20110127013048.000|20110127013050.000|TR0|What's interesting is that the Muslim 
20110127013050.000|20110127013053.000|TR0|brotherhood, the largest political 
20110127013053.000|20110127013055.000|TR0|opposition bloc in Egypt is not taking 
20110127013055.000|20110127013057.000|TR0|part in these demonstrations.  They're 
20110127013057.000|20110127013100.000|TR0|taking part as members, but as a group, it 
20110127013100.000|20110127013102.000|TR0|declined to participate.  And what this 
20110127013102.000|20110127013104.000|TR0|really is, is at least, until now, is a 
20110127013104.000|20110127013107.000|TR0|secular movement.  It has no religious

20110127013109.000|20110127013111.000|TR0|
20110127013111.000|20110127013113.000|TR0|SPITZER:  Ben Wedeman in Cairo, thank you
